race.name: Rooted Vermont
race.tagline: Vermont rolling to mountainous gravel in Morrisville.

climate.description: Variable conditions with cool temperatures possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling to mountainous northern Vermont. Moderate to significant elevation with mountain and rural scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional VT event. Vermont terrain is nice but moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Rooted Vermont is a regional event in northern Vermont's Morrisville. The rolling to mountainous terrain offers moderate to significant climbing with mountain scenery, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Morrisville provides moderate access. It's a solid regional event for Vermont cyclists.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Vermont gravel race with mountain terrain. Worth it for Vermont cyclists seeking a local mountain event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Vermont rolling to mountainous gravel in Morrisville.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Vermont and want a local mountain gravel event—yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Vermont events: Vermont Overland, Rasputitsa. For similar regional events: other VT gravel races.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Morrisville has limited lodging. Stowe or Burlington have more options.
logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.signature_challenge: Vermont mountain climbing in northern Vermont.

non_negotiables.why: Vermont mountains require solid climbing fitness (5000 feet).
Vermont weather is variable with cool conditions possible.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Vermont rolling to mountainous gravel in Morrisville.

logistics.explanation: Adam Roberge praised the "post-race meal of pulled pork sliders, salmon and pork poke bowls, and maple creemies" along with excellent volunteer support. However, the race was "placed on pause for 2023" with no current registration or contact information available, making it essentially inaccessible despite past organizational quality.

length.explanation: The actual Sip of Sunshine long course runs 85 miles, not 75. Adam Roberge notes the "relatively short course distance — 85 miles versus 100 or 200 — allows a lot more guys to be in the mix, so you need to go hard from the beginning." Elite winning times of 4:11-4:41 confirm it's substantial but manageable. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Katie Kantzes described "technical single track with plenty of rocks and, of course, roots" plus multiple Class IV sections at miles 20 and 50. Adam Roberge noted the race was "decided on a section of steep fourth-class road with chicken-head gravel surface." The course features an "uphill singletrack finish after blasting through soapy foam." Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: The long course delivers 8,000-9,500 feet of climbing over 85 miles, with Katie Kantzes noting "almost 9,000 feet of climbing with a massive kick in the teeth, cat 4 climb at only mile 3." Elite riders report "long steady climbs" and "sections of steep and bouldery class 4 road" throughout the Vermont terrain. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: FrankTuna prepared for "upper 90s heat expected" by planning "4 water bottles and a gallon of sunscreen." Katie Kantzes enjoyed "clear sunshine" but other years have brought challenging conditions. Vermont summer heat combined with 9,000 feet of climbing creates serious hydration demands for August racing. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Morrisville sits around 900 feet above sea level - basically irrelevant for altitude considerations. Even Vermont's highest peaks barely crack 4000 feet, so you're never dealing with thin air or acclimatization issues. Pure sea-level lungs performance all day. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The course traverses "beautiful Vermont country side with some difficult sections" including Class IV roads that take riders deep into backcountry terrain. Anurag Saxena noted "Every time I come to Vermont I love the scenery even more" while navigating technical single track through classic New England gravel roads.

prestige.explanation: Founded in 2019 by some unnamed former World Tour pro, this race vanished after 2022 with zero trace in current Vermont gravel calendars. 309 entries with 204 on the waitlist suggests decent local interest, but complete absence from the gravel conversation means it died quietly. No notable winners, no media coverage, no community buzz - just another dead Vermont gravel experiment.

race_quality.explanation: Race hasn't run since 2022 and left behind zero useful information about course details, aid stations, or actual logistics. It moved from Richmond to supposedly Morrisville and then disappeared entirely tells you everything about organizational consistency. Hard to rate quality when the event essentially doesn't exist anymore.

experience.explanation: The three-day gravel festival includes Friday night parties, Saturday expo with shakeout rides, and extensive post-race festivities. Matt Wilson, riding his first gravel race in honor of his sister Mo Wilson, said "I cried and smiled more this weekend than ever before" experiencing the Vermont gravel community.

community.explanation: The "mullet protocol" philosophy emphasizes "business at the front, party at the back" with over 100 people chanting and ringing cowbells for the last finisher. Samantha Fox noted "You can show up at Rooted and you know people, you aren't alone. There is no other race event where that is the case."

field_depth.explanation: A defunct race in rural Vermont that never made it past year three isn't pulling serious talent. 309 total entries suggests decent participation but nothing approaching competitive depth. Former World Tour pro connection might have brought some ringers early on, but clearly not enough to sustain the event. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Ted King puts it: "The vast majority is on this fast gravel, so if you were a really adept racer you might just get by on a road bike with really wide tyres – 34 slicks might be ok."

value.explanation: Anurag Saxena described it as "summer camp with a gravel race on the side" with extensive weekend programming including free women's clinics, expo activities, and post-race meals. The festival atmosphere and community focus deliver substantial value beyond just the race itself.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Morrisville isn't a tourist trap, so lodging and food costs stay reasonable. Rural Vermont keeps things simple - no inflated resort pricing or big city premiums. Travel costs depend on where you're coming from, but at least you're not paying entry fees for a race that doesn't run. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

unsplash_photos.description: Rustic cabins are nestled among autumn trees.
House nestled among vibrant autumn foliage on a hill.
a view of a mountain range with trees in the foreground

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: IRC Boken Double Cross
primary.why: Underrated mixed-terrain tire. Fast center with confident shoulder grip.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Iconic "MUST RIDE" Gravel Route In Vermont
videos.description:
Riding Vermont's Muddy Onion Gravel Bike Race Route: It's Iconic. It's, as we call it, a MUST RIDE, gravel cycling route. Its a well known fact that if you love to gravel cycle that Vermont is arguably the best place on earth to set a pair of tires on. With literally more gravel miles than paved, including highways, its no wonder there are gravel bike and bikepacking race events just about every week. The Muddy Onion is one of the more well known and revered races by locals and visitors. Leaving right from the states Capitol, Montpelier, you hit beautiful dirt, within only a few miles, riding through serene pastures and farmland. Every mile could be a postcard and the locals are friendly and happy to give you a wave when passing by.  I don't know of any other capitol, which feels more like a quaint small town than big city that can claim epic gravel riding just outside of its "city" limits. Welcome to Vermont its a beautiful place to be. The recent statewide historically damaging floods have put the entire state under water including Montpelier. Many businesses and homes were lost, millions of dollars and many years of repairs are needed to fix the damages. Our hearts go out to all those who endured any hardship as a result. 
Much Love to all of you that tune in to this channel. I truly look forward to interacting with each and every one of you in the comments.
#gravelbike #gravelcycling #gravelrace #gravelcyclingvermont #vermont #bikeadventures #dropbarmtb #cycling #gravelbikeroutes #cyclingrace
tags: best gravel riding in the world

videos.title: Vermont Gravel Growler - Bikepacking The Green Mountain State
videos.description:
The Vermont Gravel Growler is a 250+ mile bikepacking loop linking two of Vermont’s best qualities: gravel roads and breweries.

Follow along as Chris and Chris (and adventure pal Brett), capture their experience in a very adventure vlog style, just some GoPro and drone action, all while taking pictures along the way.


Gear Used:
Pinebury Rangely SS Jersey https://bit.ly/3zqbuqV
Pinebury Signature Merino Wool Sock https://bit.ly/3W573Lc

Our shortened version of the Bikepacking.com Gravel Growler route: https://www.strava.com/routes/3225211207902219882

Our Professional Work:
Chris Shane
https://www.instagram.com/chrismshane/ 
chrismshane.com

Chris Bennett
https://www.instagram.com/chrisbennettphoto/
chrisbennettphotography.com

videos.title: Vermont Overland 2022 - Inside the Gravel Race
videos.description:
Drawing a field of around 1,200 riders, the Vermont Overland is a gravel race that challenges all comers. While there are pros who line up to compete for top honors, it's a different story for the majority of the field behind. This video takes you inside that field as Phil and Steve ride close to 60 miles of gravel and class IV roads while climbing 7,500 feet. Along the way, they have adventures, mechanical failures and yard sales, as well as meet lots of friends, new and old.

Meet the Drowned Caterpillar; say hey to the volunteer crew from @rasputitsaspringclassic8395; have a snack under the Pure Vermont Gravel tent or at the Class 4 Designs pancake stop; meet the locals who know the one true line; draft a stinky trailer; power up at a forest pool; throw a yard sale; and fix a seat post about a hundred times: all this and more awaits you in this journey through the 2022 Vermont Overland.

Producers' note: All of the footage for this video was shot before either of us learned about the tragic loss of Sule Kangangi, professional rider for @AMANIProject and friend and colleague to many in the gravel community. We gave a lot of consideration to what to do with our footage after such a terrible shock. Ultimately we decided that since the story we tell here is true to our experience at the time, and was created in the pursuit of spreading love for gravel cycling, it would serve as a small way to honor Sule's memory and the goals he strived for.

Featured in this video:
@ovrlnd 
Suleiman "Sule" Kangangi - @AMANIProject 
Ascutney Outdoors - https://www.ascutneyoutdoors.org/
@rasputitsaspringclassic8395 - https://rasputitsadirt.com/
Pure Vermont Gravel - https://www.purevermontgravel.com/
Class 4 Designs - https://www.class4designs.com/

Chapters
00:00 - In Memory of Sule
00:21 - Meet the Drowned Caterpillar
01:42 - Titles
02:54 - Strategic Planning
05:32 - First Gravel
07:12 - More Cowbell! & Class IV Mayhem
10:24 - Lost Phil
13:19 - Found Phil
15:00 - First Aid Station
17:36 - More Mayhem
20:00 - Locals Know the Line
21:41 - Additional Mayhem
23:46 - Second Aid Station
24:53 - Draft Animals
25:41 - Yard Sale! & The Pool of Power
29:13 - Running Up That Hill
32:02 - Never Tell Me the Elevation
32:54 - Third Aid Station
34:19 - The Final Approach
36:01 - Finishing Chute
36:36 - Food! Eventually!

videos.title: The Megahopper: 9 of California's Grasshopper Gravel Races Mixed into One Massive Ride by Ted King
videos.description:
The Grasshopper Adventure Series are a staple in northern California's cycling scene. Beautiful mixed terrain events snaking all over Sonoma County. The Megahopper is an amalgamation of nine Grasshoppers in one truly epic ride covering 415 miles and more than 43,000 feet of elevation gain.

With the goal of an OKT (only known time) to help introduce this route to the public, Ted set out with videographers Avery Stumm and Adin Beard to see how quickly he could cover the route and showcase it for the masses. 

Bike:
Cannondale SuperSix EVO SE
SRAM Red/Eagle Drivetrain. 46t front chainring, 10-50 Eagle Cassette
SRAM Red calipers and levers
Zipp Firecrest 303 Wheelset
Zipp cockpit: stem + handlebars
Rene Herse 700x48mm Hatcher Pass tires
Moosepacks half-frame bag in Harlequin
Outvi Possm saddle bag
Cycliq Fly 6 rear light/camera

Velocio kit
ROKA eyewear

UnTapped nutrition. A lot of UnTapped nutrition. Yum yum.

Ride link: https://ridewithgps.com/trips/76213302
